reasons.description: Recent electoral breakthroughs abroad show voters will back fully libertarian platforms when economic or political discontent is high, proving the model can win power and govern.

sources.title: Reuters: Argentina elected radical libertarian Javier Milei as president

reasons.description: Growing voter dissatisfaction with the two major U.S. parties leaves political space for Libertarian candidates who now reach ballot access in 40‑plus states, giving them a feasible electoral path.

sources.title: POLITICO: Where third‑party candidates could spoil 2024
Brookings Institution: What does the Libertarian Party want to be when it grows up?

reasons.description: Libertarian ideas—minimal regulation, fiscal restraint and expansive civil liberties—now influence mainstream policy debates, showing their practical adoption without requiring a full third‑party takeover.

sources.title: The Economist: Michael Lind’s ‘bad argument’ against anything (debate on trying libertarianism)

objections.description: U.S. ballot‑access laws and first‑past‑the‑post elections impose costly, state‑by‑state hurdles that keep Libertarians off many ballots and out of major debates.

sources.title: Reuters: How U.S. states make it tough for third parties in elections

objections.description: Factional infighting—highlighted by brawls at the 2024 Libertarian National Convention—undermines party cohesion and deters donors, activists and swing voters.

sources.title: POLITICO: Libertarian convention devolves into fighting, obscenities on eve of Trump’s visit

objections.description: Only a small share of Americans—about 9% in Pew’s typology—hold consistently libertarian views, limiting the potential voter base for a pure libertarian platform.

sources.title: Pew Research Center: In Search of Ideologues in America

objections.description: Commentary in The Economist argues that the uncompromising ‘purity’ demanded by many libertarians prevents the pragmatic coalition‑building needed for electoral success.

sources.title: The Economist: The problems of purity

research.title: Feasibility Claims in the Debate over Anarchy versus the Minimal State
research.description: Libertarian Papers (2018) dissects how ‘feasibility’ arguments shape intra‑libertarian disputes between anarchists and minarchists, clarifying practical versus utopian proposals.

research.title: Explaining the Differential Success of Left‑Libertarian Parties
research.description: Social Forces (2000) uses qualitative comparative analysis to identify electoral systems and opportunity structures that let libertarian‑green parties break through.

research.title: Left‑Libertarian Parties: Explaining Innovation in Competitive Party Systems
research.description: World Politics (1988) shows that new libertarian parties emerge where post‑materialist cleavages align with permissive electoral rules, offering a framework for future prospects.

research.title: Freedom from Libertarianism
research.description: Journal of Contemporary Legal Issues (2025) traces how libertarian economic ideas reshape policy in the UK and U.S. while highlighting limits of ideological purity in practice.

research.title: How Status Preferences Undermine Libertarian Political Stability
research.description: University of California dissertation (2021) argues that social‑status motivations erode support for minimal‑state arrangements, challenging long‑term political sustainability.
